thread.title: NSW government to free up $1bn with car fleet shift
thread.title_full: NSW government to free up $1bn with car fleet shift | Business Spectator

author: David Swan
title: NSW government to free up $1bn with car fleet shift
text:
The NSW government is continuing to push an innovation agenda with is transport assets, announcing a new model to manage the state’s car fleet it says will free up around $1 billion in capital across four years.
Minister for Finance, Services and Property, Dominic Perrottet said state would embrace competitive sourcing from the private sector and would leverage the sharing economy.
“Today the NSW Government spends hundreds of millions of dollars buying, owning and maintaining one of the biggest car fleets in the country,” he said.
“I’d like to see this capital freed up and invested in frontline services and productive infrastructure.
“Our new fleet management model features a diversity of supply options that will improve service quality, make use of car-sharing and drive value for taxpayer money.”
Mr Perrottet said StateFleet currently includes over 22,000 passenger and light commercial vehicles at an annual cost to taxpayers of around $240 million, and the new model will see a fleet manager engaged by each agency who will deal directly with a separate panel of vehicle leasing companies.
The existing fleet will be wound down over time, Mr Perrotet said, adding that the NSW Government will shortly commence negotiations with short-listed suppliers for the new state fleet supply model.
The decision follows a 2014 report from PricewaterhouseCoopers which recommended that competition be introduced in fleet leasing and management services, recommendations the government has adopted.
The minister also announced the government will roll out car-sharing in metro areas, following the success of a recent trial. The three month trial was undertaken at Department of Finance, Services and Innovation (DFSI) offices using Goget and Hertz 24/7 share-cars.
He said staff who participated in the carshare trial reported a high degree of satisfaction, enjoyed not having to fill in log books and were able to use share cars located near their homes.
“We should be looking use these new economy services wherever it is feasible and practical,” said Mr Perrottet. “Car sharing is flexible, cost effective and convenient.”
GoGet CEO Tristan Sender said he hoped the NSW’s lead would result in carshare being rolled out across all departments.
This article was first published in The Australian Business Review.
